newsitem.title: JAPAN: Tokyo naphtha gains ground, LSWR firmer.
newsitem.headline: Tokyo naphtha gains ground, LSWR firmer.

text.p: Naphtha prices were notionally firmer in late afternoon Tokyo trade on Monday in reaction to Friday's crude surges on overseas markets, traders said.
However, market participants were mostly on the sidelines, unsure of market direction after the sharp increase in crude prices on Friday.
Open-spec naphtha for second-half February was assessed at $233.00/236.00. It was sold to a Japanese trading house at $230.00 on Friday.
First-half March was quoted about $3.00 to $4.00 per tonne lower than the second-half February level.
The backwardation in naphtha's inter-delivery spreads shrank further, with first-half February/first-half March indicated at plus $6.00/7.50, compared to Friday's $7.00/8.00.
Low-sulphur waxy residue (LSWR) prices gained further ground, with spot cargoes quoted over $25.00 per barrel on a free-on-board (FOB) basis.

Traders said the current LSWR prices, which have surpassed benchmark West Texas Intermediate (WTI) prices, are "exceptionally high." LSWR prices are usually about $4.00 per barrel lower than WTI prices, they added.
